details.title: A Wear Model for Assessing the Reliability of Cylinder Liners in Marine Diesel Engines

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Aerosp. & Mech. Eng, Second Univ. of Napoli

p: Massimiliano Giorgio is an Associate Professor of “Statistics and Calculus of Probability” at the Second University of Naples (Italy). In 1991, he graduated in Mechanical Engineering at the University of Naples Federico II. From 1991 to 1993, he joined Istituto Motori of the National Research Council. In 1997, he received his PhD in Computational Statistics and Applications from the Department of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Naples Federico II. From 1998 to 2000, he was employed in the RAMS division at the Ansaldo Trasporti. From 2000 to 2001, he was a researcher at the University of Naples Federico II. Since 1996, he has been giving courses in “Statistical Quality Control,” “Reliability Theory,” and “Statistic and Calculus of Probability” at the University of Sannio, the University of Naples Federico II, and the Second University of Naples. His research interests include reliability, quality control, and applied statistics.

authors.name: Massimiliano Giorgio

p: Maurizio Guida is a Full Professor of Statistics in the Department of Information Engineering and Electrical Engineering at the University of Salerno (Italy). He previously worked at the Istituto Motori of the Italian National Research Council where he directed the Department of Statistics, and Reliability. He also held several teaching positions at the Federico II University of Naples, and the University of Benevento as an Adjoint Professor of Statistical Methods for Quality Control. His research interests are in the field of reliability theory & applications, and applied statistics.

Gianpaolo Pulcini is currently a Senior Researcher in the Department of Statistics and Reliability at the Istituto Motori of the National Research Council (CNR) of Italy, and an Adjoint Professor of Statistics and Reliability at the Parthenope University of Naples. He received his Doctor degree (1982) in Aeronautical Engineering from the University of Naples, Italy. His major research interests are in mechanical reliability modeling, and related statistical topics, mainly oriented towards Bayesian statistics.

details.abstract: Stringent in-service and operating requirements oblige marine diesel engines to possess high levels of reliability and availability. To achieve the desired reliability and availability levels, it is necessary to carry out costly maintenance activity on the cylinder liners, the wear on which is a major factor in causing diesel engine failure. This paper presents a s-based methodology that can be used to carry out a condition-based estimate of liner reliability with respect to failure through excessive wear, and to plan condition-based maintenance activity. The wear process is described through an ad hoc cumulative damage model, and the reliability of the liners is estimated on the basis of wear measures, and predictions of wear increase. The approach proposed allows reducing maintenance costs without noticeably affecting liner reliability. In fact, it gives the probability of inspecting or replacing liners only when there is a high likelihood that their wear level will exceed the wear limit before the next inspection date. The proposed model, and planning procedure have been applied to a data set consisting of wear measures of the cylinder liners of two SULZER RTA 58 engines equipping twin ships of the Grimaldi Group
